questions.question: I want to know why ………………………….. late.
questions.description: In indirect questions, the subject goes before the verb.

questions.question: If she had asked me, I …………………………….. her.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: She would have come if you …………………………….. her.
questions.description: In the third conditional, we use a past perfect tense in the if-clause and would have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: We are looking forward ……………………………. you.
questions.description: Write to + ing form after look forward/looking forward.

questions.question: The more you praise him the more arrogant …………………………..
questions.description: The same pattern is used in both clauses.

questions.question: The louder you speak ………………………………. you confuse me.
questions.description: The + comparative is used in both clauses.

questions.question: Would you mind …………………………… me your pen?
questions.description: Ing forms or if-clauses are used after would you mind.

questions.question: …………………………… you study well, you cannot pass.
questions.description: If is grammatically correct in that sentence, but it does not make logical sense.

questions.question: If I were the king, you ………………………………. my queen.
questions.description: In the second conditional, we use past simple in the if-clause and would + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: She is very fond ……………………………. her cats and dogs.
He enjoys ……………………………….. with children.
questions.description: Write an ing form after enjoy.
